fr:mainmatter.html:p: I have been thinking about monoidal closed structures induced by slicing over a monoid, which has been considered by Combette and Munch-Maccagnoni as a potential denotational semantics of destructors à la C++. It occurred to me that this construction is, in fact, almost a degenerate case of Day convolution on an internal monoidal category — and this made me realize that there might be a nice way to understand Day convolution in the language of fibered categories. In fact, many of these results (in particular the relativization to internal monoidal categories) are probably a special case of Theorem 11.22 of Shulman’s paper on enriched indexed categories.

Let E and F be two fibered categories over a semimonoidal category {\mathopen {}\left (B,\otimes ,\alpha \right )\mathclose {}}. We may define the “Day tensor” product E\otimes _B F of E and F to be the following fibered category over B:
Note that f_! refers to the left adjoint of base change f^* for fibered categories, which is not postcomposition.

fr:title.text: Stepping through the Day tensor of fibered categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Stepping through the Day tensor of fibered categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: To understand the construction of the Day tensor, we will go through it step-by-step. Let E and F be two fibered categories over a semimonoidal category {\mathopen {}\left (B,\otimes ,\alpha \right )\mathclose {}}.

html:ol.html:li:
Next, we took the fiber product of fibered categories, giving a vertical span over B:
\pi _1^*E \leftarrow \pi _1^*E\times _{B\times B} \pi _2^*F \rightarrow \pi _2^*F
Of course, this corresponds to pullback in \mathbf {Cat} or cartesian product in {\mathbf {Cat}}_{/B}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Under appropriate assumptions, we may also compute a “Day hom” by adjointness.

Let E and F be two fibered categories over a semimonoidal category {\mathopen {}\left (B,\otimes ,\alpha \right )\mathclose {}}. We may define the “Day hom” E\multimap _B F of E and F to be the following fibered category over B:

First of all, we note that the pullback functor {{\mathbf {Cat}}_{/B}}\xrightarrow {{\pi _1^*}}{{\mathbf {Cat}}_{/B\times B}} has a right adjoint \pi _1^*\dashv {\mathopen {}\left (\pi _1\right )\mathclose {}}_*, as {B\times B}\xrightarrow {{\pi _1}}{B} is (as any cartesian fibration) a Conduché functor, i.e. an exponentiable arrow in \mathbf {Cat}. We have already assumed that E is a Cartesian fibration, and thus so is its restriction \pi _1^*E; it therefore follows that \pi _1^*E is exponentiable. With that out of the way, we may compute the hom by adjoint calisthenics:

Let {\mathopen {}\left (B,\otimes ,I,\alpha ,\lambda ,\rho \right )\mathclose {}} be a monoidal category. We may define a “Day unit” for fibered categories over B to be given by the discrete fibration {B}_{/I}\to B, which corresponds under the Grothendieck construction to the presheaf represented by I.

fr:title.text: The Day tensor preserves cartesian fibrations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The Day tensor preserves cartesian fibrations

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If E and F are cartesian fibrations over a semimonoidal category {\mathopen {}\left (B,\otimes ,\alpha \right )\mathclose {}}, then the Day tensor E\otimes _BF is also a cartesian fibration.

I believe, but did not check carefully, that when E and F are discrete fibrations over a semimonoidal category {\mathopen {}\left (B,\otimes ,\alpha \right )\mathclose {}} then the Day tensor is precisely the discrete fibration corresponding to the (contravariant) Day convolution of the presheaves corresponding to E and F. Likewise when {\mathopen {}\left (B,\otimes ,I,\alpha ,\lambda ,\rho \right )\mathclose {}} is monoidal, it appears that the Day unit corresponds precisely to the traditional one.

There remain some interesting directions to explore. First of all, the claims above would obviously lead to a new construction of the Day convolution monoidal structure on the 1-category of discrete fibrations on B that coincides with the traditional one up to the Grothendieck construction. But in general, we should expect to exhibit both {\mathbf {Cat}}_{/B} and \mathbf {Fib}_{B} as monoidal bicategories, a result that I have not seen before.

fr:title.text: A monoidal bicategory of fibered categories

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A monoidal bicategory of fibered categories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {\mathopen {}\left (B,\otimes ,I,\alpha ,\lambda ,\rho \right )\mathclose {}} be a fibered category. Then the Day tensor and unit extend to a monoidal structure on the bicategory of fibered categories over B.

Conjecture is highly non-trivial, as monoidal bicategories are extremely difficult to construct explicitly. I am hoping that Mike Shulman’s ideas involving monoidal double categories could potentially help.

fr:title.text: Splitting the generic element of the generic cone

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Splitting the generic element of the generic cone

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The underlying function p_{I}:I\to I of the generic element p_{I}:I\multimap I of the generic cone p_{\bullet }:\mathchoice {\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\textstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}{\scriptscriptstyle \prod _{{\mathopen {}\left (X:{A}\downarrow {\mathcal {U}}\right )\mathclose {}}}}I\multimap X under I \equiv \widetilde {\mathsf {SemiCoh}} has been equipped with the structure of a quasi-idempotent in the sense of Shulman, so we may split it.

In particular, the construction of Shulman gives us a type J together with a retraction r : I\to J and a section s : J \to I witnessed by a homotopy \rho :{s;r} \sim _{J\to J} {1_{J}}, such that r;s\equiv p_{I} : I \to I definitionally. Our goal is to lift this splitting of the underlying function p_{I}:I\to I to a splitting of the homomorphism p_{I}:I\multimap I.

We may equip J with the structure of a reflection algebra by setting \eta _{J} :\equiv \eta _{I};r, making r : I \multimap J a homomorphism of algebras definitionally, i.e. \eta _{r}a:\equiv \mathsf {refl}. To exhibit s : J \multimap I as a homomorphism of algebras, we may likewise use reflexivity:
That the above is well-defined can be deduced as follows, using the fact that the splitting of p_{I}\equiv r;s is definitional and that p_{I} is a definitional homomorphism:
We have to check that the homotopy of functions \rho : {s;r} \sim _{J\to J} {1_{J}} lifts to a homotopy of homomorphisms. In particular, we must construct the coherence \bar \rho specified below:

Note that \eta _{1_{J}} is reflexivity; we compute the other side of the desired identificiation \bar \rho a by unfolding definitions (e.g. that of identities and compositions of homomorphisms) and using basic path algebra:

Therefore, to construct \bar \rho a is suffices to identify \rho {\mathopen {}\left (r{\mathopen {}\left (\eta _{I}a\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} with reflexivity. To do so, we will use an argument suggested by Shulman in private conversation. We recall from Theorem 3.3 of Shulman that the homotopy \rho induces a new witness of pre-idempotency for p_{I}, namely \chi ' x :\equiv \mathsf {ap}_{s}{\mathopen {}\left (\rho {\mathopen {}\left (rx\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} and that by Theorem 7.1 of the same, this homotopy may be identified with our original witness \chi : {p_{I};p_{I}} \sim _{I\to I} {p_{I}}. Therefore we have \mathsf {ap}_{s}{\mathopen {}\left (\rho {\mathopen {}\left (rx\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} = \vartheta _{x}p_{I}; because s is a section of r, this implies that \rho {\mathopen {}\left (r x\right )\mathclose {}} = \mathsf {ap}_{r}{\mathopen {}\left (\vartheta _{x}p_{I}\right )\mathclose {}} and so we may compute our identification \bar \rho \, a as follows:
Above we have used the fact that the coherence datum \eta _{p_{I}}a is reflexivity.

By the contractibility of singletons and our characterization of paths between homomorphisms, the definition of semicoherence structures is equivalent to following more direct formulation that avoids the additional cell \phi :

Our reason for choosing the more complex definition involving {\mathopen {}\left (h,\phi \right )\mathclose {}} is that the extra flexibility comes in handy in our results, as suggested by Michael Shulman in private communication.

fr:title.text: Wild initial objects from universal cones

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Wild initial objects from universal cones

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category, and let I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} be an object of \mathcal {C}. If we may equip a wild natural transformation {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} from the constant 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta I}}{\mathcal {C}} to the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} with an identification c_\alpha : \alpha _I = 1_{I}, then \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} is contractible for all A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}.

(Our proof will follow that of the nLab, which was stated for ordinary categories and functors and natural transformations rather than wild ones. It was Mike Shulman who noticed who noticed that this proof also works for the wild/incoherent notions studied here.)

To show that \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} is contractible, we choose \alpha _{A} : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} as the center of contraction. To identify any f : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} with \alpha _{A}, we use the wild naturality of {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}}. In particular, we have an identification \alpha _f between \alpha _I;f and 1_{I};\alpha _A. By our assumption that \alpha _I=1_{I} and using the wild left-unit identifications \lambda f and \lambda \alpha _A, we may identify f with \alpha _A.

We describe some basic definitions and results in “wild (incoherent) category theory”, i.e. the study of untruncated category-like objects in univalent foundations that may lack higher coherences and saturation/completeness assumptions. Some of this is based on the Homotopy Type Theory Coq library, as well as ideas from a blog post of Mike Shulman and private conversations with Mike Shulman.
A wild category is given by the following data:

html:ol.html:li: for each A,B:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}, a family of types \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}};

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}}, an element {\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,C\right )\mathclose {}}

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}}, a identification \mathsf {lunit}_{\mathcal {C}} f : {\mathopen {}\left (1_{A};f\right )\mathclose {}} = f and a identification \mathsf {runit}_{\mathcal {C}} f : {\mathopen {}\left (f;1_{B}\right )\mathclose {}}=f;

for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}} and h:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}}, a identification \mathsf {assoc}_{\mathcal {C}}\,f\,g\,h : f;{\mathopen {}\left (g;h\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}};h.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The definitions here are adapted from Shulman from the setting of intensional type theory to an arbitrary wild category.

Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; a pre-idempotent on an object A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} is defined to be a morphism f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,A\right )\mathclose {}} together with an identification \phi : f;f = f.

Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; a quasi-idempotent on an object A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} is defined to be a pre-idempotent {\mathopen {}\left (f,\phi \right )\mathclose {}} on A together with an identification \chi between f;\phi : f;{\mathopen {}\left (f;f\right )\mathclose {}} = f;f and the following composite identification:
Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be two wild categories. A wild 0-functor from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D} is given by the following data:
In other words, a wild 0-functor is a homomorphism of the underlying graphs.

Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be two wild categories. A wild 1-semi-functor from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D} is given by a wild 0-functor F : \mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} equipped with, for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}} and g : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (C,D\right )\mathclose {}}, an identification \mathsf {seq}_F\,f\,g : \mathbf {hom}_{F}{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} = \mathbf {hom}_{F}{f};\mathbf {hom}_{G}{g} .
Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category; the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} on \mathcal {C} is defined as follows:
The above may be extended to a wild 1-semi-functor as follows:

Let \mathcal {C} and \mathcal {D} be wild categories, and let D:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} be an object of \mathcal {D}. We define the constant 0-functor on D:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {D}} out of \mathcal {C} to be the 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta D}}{\mathcal {D}} defined as follows:
The above may be extended to a wild 1-semi-functor as follows:

Let \mathcal {C},\mathcal {D} be two wild categories, and let F,G:\mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be two wild 0-functors from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D}. A wild natural transformation is defined by the following data:

Let \mathcal {C},\mathcal {D} be two wild categories, and let F,G:\mathcal {C}\to \mathcal {D} be two wild 1-semi-functors from \mathcal {C} to \mathcal {D}. A wild semi-coherent natural transformation is defined by the data of a wild natural transformation \alpha : F \to G together with, for each f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} and g : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (B,C\right )\mathclose {}}, a higher identification \mathsf {seq}_{\alpha }\,f\,g between \alpha _{f;g} : F{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}};\alpha _{C} = \alpha _{A};G{\mathopen {}\left (f;g\right )\mathclose {}} and the composite identification:

fr:title.text: Wild initial objects from universal cones

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Wild initial objects from universal cones

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category, and let I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} be an object of \mathcal {C}. If we may equip a wild natural transformation {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} from the constant 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta I}}{\mathcal {C}} to the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} with an identification c_\alpha : \alpha _I = 1_{I}, then \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} is contractible for all A:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}.

(Our proof will follow that of the nLab, which was stated for ordinary categories and functors and natural transformations rather than wild ones. It was Mike Shulman who noticed who noticed that this proof also works for the wild/incoherent notions studied here.)

To show that \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} is contractible, we choose \alpha _{A} : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} as the center of contraction. To identify any f : \mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,A\right )\mathclose {}} with \alpha _{A}, we use the wild naturality of {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}}. In particular, we have an identification \alpha _f between \alpha _I;f and 1_{I};\alpha _A. By our assumption that \alpha _I=1_{I} and using the wild left-unit identifications \lambda f and \lambda \alpha _A, we may identify f with \alpha _A.

fr:title.text: A wild universal cone from a splitting of the generic element

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A wild universal cone from a splitting of the generic element

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a wild category, and let I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}} be an object of \mathcal {C} such that {\Delta I}\xrightarrow {{\alpha }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} is a wild natural transformation from the constant 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{\Delta I}}{\mathcal {C}} to the identity 0-functor {\mathcal {C}}\xrightarrow {{1_{\mathcal {C}}}}{\mathcal {C}} on \mathcal {C} for some I:\mathbf {ob}_{\mathcal {C}}. Now let r:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,J\right )\mathclose {}} and s:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (J,I\right )\mathclose {}} be a section-retraction pair witnessed by \eta : s;r = 1_{I}, and let \sigma : r;s=\alpha _{I} be a splitting of \alpha _{I}:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (I,I\right )\mathclose {}}. Then we may define a wild natural transformation {\Delta J}\xrightarrow {{\beta }}{1_{\mathcal {C}}} and an identification \chi : \beta _{J} = 1_{J}.
(This construction is due to Mike Shulman.)

Define the component \beta _{A}:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (J,A\right )\mathclose {}} to be the composite s;\alpha _{A}; for the wild naturality structure, we fix f:\mathbf {hom}_{\mathcal {C}}{\mathopen {}\left (A,B\right )\mathclose {}} to define \beta _{f} : \beta _{A};f = 1_{J};\beta _{B} as follows:

Next we identify \beta _{J} with 1_{J}. By incoherent naturality, we have \alpha _{J};s = \alpha _{I}; thus by our splitting of \alpha _{I} we have \alpha _{J};s = r;s and hence by postcomposing r and canceling via \eta :s;r=1_{I} we conclude that \alpha _J = r. Therefore \beta _J=s;\alpha _J=s;r=1_{J}.

fr:title.text: Cubical exact equality and categorical gluing

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Cubical exact equality and categorical gluing
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: International Conference on Homotopy Type Theory, 2019

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We contribute XTT, a cubical reconstruction of Observational Type Theory which extends intensional type theory with a dependent equality type that enjoys function extensionality and judgmental unicity of identity proofs. XTT employs a variant of the Cartesian cubical Kan operations satisfying regularity (i.e., transport in constant type families is judgmentally constant), allowing its equality type to model Martin-Lof’s identity type judgmentally. We prove canonicity for the initial model of XTT (i.e., any closed term of boolean type is equal to either true or false) using a novel cubical extension (independently proposed by Awodey) of the categorical gluing technique inspired by Coquand and Shulman, in which we glue the fundamental fibration of a category of augmented Cartesian cubical sets along a cubical nerve. We conjecture that our methods will extend to open terms, allowing us to establish normalization and decidability of the typing relation.

fr:title.text: IAS Special Year on Univalent Foundations

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: IAS Special Year on Univalent Foundations

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A Special Year on Univalent Foundations of Mathematics was held in 2012-13 at the Institute for Advanced Study, School of Mathematics, organized by Steve Awodey, Thierry Coquand, and Vladimir Voevodsky. The following people were the official participants:
There were also the following students, whose participation was no less valuable.
In addition, there were the following short- and long-term visitors, including student visitors, whose contributions to the Special Year were also essential.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Strict universes for Grothendieck topoi
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @unpublished{gratzer-shulman-sterling-2024-universes, author = {Gratzer, Daniel and Shulman, Michael and Sterling, Jonathan}, year = {2024}, month = may, doi = {10.48550/arXiv.2202.12012}, eprint = {2202.12012}, eprintclass = {math.CT}, eprinttype = {arXiv}, note = {Unpublished manuscript}, title = {Strict universes for Grothendieck topoi}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Hofmann and Streicher famously showed how to lift Grothendieck universes into presheaf topoi, and Streicher has extended their result to the case of sheaf topoi by sheafification. In parallel, van den Berg and Moerdijk have shown in the context of algebraic set theory that similar constructions continue to apply even in weaker metatheories. Unfortunately, sheafification seems not to preserve an important realignment property enjoyed by presheaf universes that plays a critical role in models of univalent type theory as well as synthetic Tait computability. When multiple universes are present, realignment also implies a coherent interpretation of connectives across all universes that justifies the cumulativity laws present in popular formulations of Martin-Löf type theory.

We observe that a slight adjustment to an argument of Shulman constructs a cumulative universe hierarchy satisfying the realignment property at every level in any Grothendieck topos. Hence one has direct-style interpretations of Martin-Löf type theory with cumulative universes into all Grothendieck topoi. A further implication is to extend the reach of recent synthetic methods in the semantics of cubical type theory and the syntactic metatheory of type theory and programming languages to all Grothendieck topoi.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Idempotents in intensional type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{shulman-2016, author = {Shulman, Michael}, year = {2016}, month = apr, doi = {10.2168/LMCS-12(3:9)2016}, issue = {3}, journal = {Logical Methods in Computer Science}, title = {{Idempotents in intensional type theory}}, volume = {12}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We study idempotents in intensional Martin-Löf type theory, and in particular the question of when and whether they split. We show that in the presence of propositional truncation and Voevodsky’s univalence axiom, there exist idempotents that do not split; thus in plain MLTT not all idempotents can be proven to split. On the other hand, assuming only function extensionality, an idempotent can be split if and only if its witness of idempotency satisfies one extra coherence condition. Both proofs are inspired by parallel results of Lurie in higher category theory, showing that ideas from higher category theory and homotopy theory can have applications even in ordinary MLTT.

Finally, we show that although the witness of idempotency can be recovered from a splitting, the one extra coherence condition cannot in general; and we construct “the type of fully coherent idempotents”, by splitting an idempotent on the type of partially coherent ones. Our results have been formally verified in the proof assistant Coq.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The directed plump ordering
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @unpublished{gratzer-shulman-sterling-2022-plump, author = {Gratzer, Daniel and Shulman, Michael and Sterling, Jonathan}, year = {2022}, doi = {10.48550/arXiv.2202.07329}, eprint = {2202.07329}, eprintclass = {cs.LO}, eprinttype = {arXiv}, title = {The directed plump ordering}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Based on Taylor's hereditarily directed plump ordinals, we define the directed plump ordering on W-types in Martin-Löf type theory. This ordering is similar to the plump ordering but comes equipped with non-empty finite joins in additional to the usual properties of the plump ordering.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Modalities in homotopy type theory
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{rijke-shulman-spitters-2020, author = {Rijke, Egbert and Shulman, Michael and Spitters, Bas}, year = {2020}, month = jan, doi = {10.23638/LMCS-16(1:2)2020}, issue = {1}, journal = {Logical Methods in Computer Science}, title = {Modalities in homotopy type theory}, volume = {16}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We prove the conjecture that any Grothendieck (\infty ,1)-topos can be presented by a Quillen model category that interprets homotopy type theory with strict univalent universes. Thus, homotopy type theory can be used as a formal language for reasoning internally to (\infty ,1)-toposes, just as higher-order logic is used for 1-toposes. As part of the proof, we give a new, more explicit, characterization of the fibrations in injective model structures on presheaf categories. In particular, we show that they generalize the coflexible algebras of 2-monad theory.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A type theory for synthetic ∞-categories
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{riehl-shulman-2017, author = {Riehl, Emily and Shulman, Michael}, url = {https://journals.mq.edu.au/index.php/higher_structures/article/view/36}, year = {2017}, eprint = {1705.07442}, eprintclass = {math.CT}, eprinttype = {arXiv}, issue = {1}, journal = {Higher Structures}, pages = {147--224}, title = {A type theory for synthetic $\infty$-categories}, volume = {1}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We propose foundations for a synthetic theory of (∞,1)-categories within homotopy type theory. We axiomatize a directed interval type, then define higher simplices from it and use them to probe the internal categorical structures of arbitrary types. We define Segal types, in which binary composites exist uniquely up to homotopy; this automatically ensures composition is coherently associative and unital at all dimensions. We define Rezk types, in which the categorical isomorphisms are additionally equivalent to the type-theoretic identities - a “local univalence” condition. And we define covariant fibrations, which are type families varying functorially over a Segal type, and prove a “dependent Yoneda lemma” that can be viewed as a directed form of the usual elimination rule for identity types. We conclude by studying homotopically correct adjunctions between Segal types, and showing that for a functor between Rezk types to have an adjoint is a mere proposition.

To make the bookkeeping in such proofs manageable, we use a three-layered type theory with shapes, whose contexts are extended by polytopes within directed cubes, which can be abstracted over using “extension types” that generalize the path-types of cubical type theory. In an appendix, we describe the motivating semantics in the Reedy model structure on bisimplicial sets, in which our Segal and Rezk types correspond to Segal spaces and complete Segal spaces.

fr:title.text: The univalence axiom for elegant Reedy presheaves

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The univalence axiom for elegant Reedy presheaves
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{shulman-2015-elegant, author = {Shulman, Michael}, year = {2015}, doi = {10.4310/HHA.2015.v17.n2.a6}, eprint = {1307.6248}, eprintclass = {math.AT}, eprinttype = {arXiv}, issue = {2}, journal = {Homology, Homotopy and Applications}, pages = {81--106}, title = {The Univalence Axiom for Elegant Reedy Presheaves}, volume = {17}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We show that Voevodsky’s univalence axiom for homotopy type theory is valid in categories of simplicial presheaves on elegant Reedy categories. In addition to diagrams on inverse categories, as considered in previous work of the author, this includes bisimplicial sets and \Theta _n-spaces. This has potential applications to the study of homotopical models for higher categories.

fr:title.text: Univalent categories and the Rezk completion

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Univalent categories and the Rezk completion
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{ahrens-kapulkin-shulman-2015, title={Univalent categories and the Rezk completion}, volume={25}, doi={10.1017/S0960129514000486}, number={5}, journal={Mathematical Structures in Computer Science}, publisher={Cambridge University Press}, author={Ahrens, Benedikt and Kapulkin, Krzysztof and Shulman, Michael}, year={2015}, pages={1010–1039} }

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Enriched indexed categories
fr:frontmatter.fr:meta: @article{shulman-2013, author = {Shulman, Michael}, year = {2013}, journal = {Theory and Applications of Categories}, number = {21}, pages = {616--695}, title = {Enriched indexed categories}, volume = {28}, }

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We develop a theory of categories which are simultaneously (1) indexed over a base category S with finite products, and (2) enriched over an S-indexed monoidal category V. This includes classical enriched categories, indexed and fibered categories, and internal categories as special cases. We then describe the appropriate notion of “limit” for such enriched indexed categories, and show that they admit “free cocompletions” constructed as usual with a Yoneda embedding.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Constructing symmetric monoidal bicategories

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We present a method of constructing symmetric monoidal bicategories from symmetric monoidal double categories that satisfy a lifting condition. Such symmetric monoidal double categories frequently occur in nature, so the method is widely applicable, though not universally so.
